awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interhemispheric and Zonal Asymmetries of the ITCZ
awd_abstract_narration:
Satellites views of the earth typically show a narrow band of deep precipitating clouds over the tropical oceans where the trade winds converge.  This band, known as the inter-tropical convergence zone, or ITCZ, is generally found north of the equator with a mean latitude of about 6N.  Many aspects of the ITCZ including its existence, its role in global atmospheric circulation, and its preference for the Northern Hemisphere can be understood by thinking of the ITCZ as a uniform strip of convection with the same width, central latitude, and rainfall intensity at all longitudes.  But this longitudinally averaged view of the ITCZ overlooks substantial variations in ITCZ latitude around the tropics.  In particular the ITCZ is found south of the equator in the Indian Ocean and it has a southwest to northeast slope across both the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.  The latitude of the ITCZ can thus be anywhere from from 4S to 10N depending on the ocean basin, the longitude within that basin, and the time of year.

This project uses combination of observational analysis and carefully designed model simulations to study regional variations in ITCZ latitude and other properties.  For instance the northward displacement of the ITCZ in the eastern Pacific has been attributed to the geography of the North and South American coastlines, an idea which can be tested through simulations in which the west coasts of the Americas are mirror images of each other.  The importance of oceanic processes is tested using simplified ocean configurations which allow some mechanisms but disable others.  Ocean model configurations include a simple motionless "slab" ocean, a modified slab ocean which captures near-surface heat transport driven by surface winds, and a "shallow water" ocean model which allows surface cooling due to the upwelling of cold water from the deep ocean.  In addition, the project develops a version of the Community Earth System Model (CESM) in which flux corrections are applied to improve the representation of the ITCZ.

The work is of practical interest given the importance of the ITCZ for tropical rainfall as well as its outsized effects on the climate and atmospheric circulation of the earth.  Despite its importance the ITCZ is not well simulated in models used for weather prediction and climate change projections, thus a better understanding of ITCZ dynamics could be quite useful for model improvement.  The work also has value for the broader research enterprise, as model configurations developed for the project will be openly available for adoption by the worldwide research community.  In addition, the award provides support and training for two graduate students, thereby contributing to scientific workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is the globe-encircling band of maximum rainfall in the tropics. The associated condensational heating drives the atmospheric circulation and forces stationary waves that influence climate across the planet. In the zonal average, the ITCZ is located around 6N. This interhemispheric asymmetry varies in the east-west direction, with the ITCZ position from 10N in the eastern Pacific to 4S in the eastern Indian Ocean. The interhemispheric and zonal asymmetries of the ITCZ are poorly simulated in state-of-the-art climate models, and the response to anthropogenic radiative forcing is not well understood.

A zonal-mean energy theory has gained popularity for its predictive power of cross-equatorial changes in the Hadley circulation and ITCZ. Research from this NSF project expanded this framework by revealing coupled ocean-atmospheric adjustment processes for extratropical radiative perturbations to reach the deep tropics. These processes give rise to important zonal variations in tropical climate change, such as the Walker circulation. Sunlight-reflecting anthropogenic aerosols are concentrated mostly in the Northern Hemisphere extratropics, requiring compensating energy transport from the Southern to Northern Hemisphere by the ocean-atmosphere system. Ocean heat transport by the meridional overturning circulations reduces the need for the atmosphere to transport energy from the warm to cool hemisphere, thereby damping the meridional displacements of the ITCZ. In addition, the aerosol forcing induces zonal variations in climate response through the so-called meridional mode, amplified by subtropical low clouds off California.

Atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, on the other hand, are nearly spatially uniform, but the ocean takes up the anthropogenic heat chiefly in the subpolar North Atlantic and Southern Ocean. We developed a model-assisted diagnostic framework to shed light on how the confined ocean heat uptake creates spatial patterns of temperature and rainfall changes in the deep tropics.

Accurate information on regional climate change is necessary for developing meaningful adaptation. By advancing physical understanding of regional climate change, our research contributes to the reduction of uncertainty in climate projections. The project trained graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in climate dynamics and modeling. Its results have been used in classroom teaching and included in a new graduate textbook.
